channel.title: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: Why China Is Winning the Trade War
item.description: Rare earths and other assets have given Beijing an edge in trade talks with Washington.

item.title: Xi Takes the Spotlight at APEC Summit in Trump’s Absence
item.description: China aims to portray itself as a champion of free trade amid high U.S. tariffs.

item.title: The Regime Change Temptation in Venezuela
item.description: If past is prologue, a U.S. attempt to overthrow Maduro would not end well.

item.title: What in the World?
item.description: Test yourself on the week of Oct. 25: Hurricane Melissa batters the Caribbean, Argentina holds midterm elections, and Trump travels through Asia.

item.title: Add This to the Canon of Great Diplomacy Books
item.description: A. Wess Mitchell’s tour through two millennia of diplomacy is catnip for foreign-policy wonks.

item.title: Moscow’s Shadow Looms Over Bratislava
item.description: Russia’s historic role remains central to the debate over Slovak foreign policy today.

item.title: China Is Stamping Out Dissident Art
item.description: Curators, painters, and performers are facing jail or exile.

item.title: Indian Politics Are a Family Business
item.description: The belief that members of political dynasties are uniquely suited to lead is woven deeply into the fabric of Indian governance, from village councils to the highest echelons of parliament. But when elected office is treated like a family heirloom, the quality of governance inevitably suffers.

item.title: The War Room newsletter: The most successful amphibious invasion
item.description: In a bonus edition of our defence newsletter, Richard Cockett takes us back to 1066—and the Battle of Hastings

item.title: The Big Lie Behind Trump’s Boat Strikes
item.description: The Trump administration is training the press and the American people to associate the military strikes on small boats in international waters with stopping the flow of fentanyl and other drugs. This mendacity is a prime example of the falsehoods that imperialists tell before launching doomed wars of aggression.

item.title: Curtis Sliwa’s tough-guy mien evokes an older New York
item.description: He won’t win the mayoral election, but his life story is more colourful than those of his rivals

item.title: The Coming US-China Thaw
item.description: After years of increasingly hostile rhetoric from US officials about China, highly authoritative voices in the United States have suddenly become less hawkish, and the Trump administration has begun to pursue new trade negotiations in earnest. Is the American establishment finally waking up to economic reality?

item.title: Europe’s Blind Spot: China’s Transnational Repression
item.description: China and other authoritarian regimes often target dissidents and minorities living abroad. The EU must do more to protect vulnerable communities.

item.title: United Council of Rohang: Bangladesh’s Script for Rohingya Leadership
item.description: The refugee camp elections did not provide not self-representation but state-supervised choreography.

item.title: Development Finance Must Shift Away from Aid
item.description: As traditional donors slash foreign-aid budgets, developing countries must mobilize a broader range of financing sources. National development banks, sovereign wealth funds, debt swaps, and public-private partnerships can foster sustainable investment and help reduce energy poverty.

item.title: Will Trump’s Critical Minerals Blitz Pay Off?
item.description: The U.S. president has been on a mission to secure new supply chains—and counter China’s grip.

item.title: Is This Central Asia’s Green Energy Reckoning?
item.description: When it comes to energy security, Central Asian governments have shown an ability to adapt to shifting global and domestic trends.

item.title: Where Afghanistan Fits in Iran’s Changing Regional Playbook
item.description: Afghanistan occupies a central position in Tehran’s changing playbook, as the country is both a risk and a buffer for Iran.

item.title: Why Trump Should Have Raised China’s Transnational Repression With Xi Jinping
item.description: Even amid de-escalation efforts, there is strategic value to rebuffing Beijing’s overreach.

item.title: How Vulnerable Is China?
item.description: The meeting between US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping may have delivered a kind of détente, after months of escalating tariff threats by the United States and retaliatory restrictions on rare-earth exports by China. While China had good reason to de-escalate the conflict with the US, however, it remains beset by political and economic weaknesses.

item.title: The Big Picture
Trump’s Pivot from Asia
item.description: After US President Donald Trump's trip to the region, one could be forgiven for concluding that the "pivot to Asia" begun when Barack Obama was in the White House has been replaced by a pivot to the Western Hemisphere. Needless to say, this is not the pivot America’s friends and allies in Asia were and are counting on.

item.title: Japan Is Sending Soldiers to Lithuania to Train Ukrainian Troops
item.description: The deployment, small as it is, marks a first for Japan in several ways.

item.title: Can a dopamine detox reset your brain?
item.description: Taken literally, the idea makes no sense. But it might still be good for you

item.title: Can China Catch Up with the US Economically?
item.description: With its GNI per capita having increased steadily in recent years, China has probably evaded the middle-income trap. But the country may yet find itself ensnared in a kind of economic Thucydides trap: attempting to surpass an incumbent hegemon bent on keeping it down – and never quite succeeding.

item.title: Beyond Hardware: The Message Behind Singapore’s New Defense Acquisitions
item.description: For Singapore, whose security rests as much on perception as on capability, defense modernization is not a discretionary choice. It is strategic signaling.

item.title: Taliban Minister Muttaqi’s Visit to Deoband Seminary in India
item.description: He was mobbed at the seminary. The rockstar welcome he received should worry Delhi.

item.title: Cheng Li-wun’s Election Raises Questions for the KMT
item.description: Cheng's position on cross-strait issues and reformist agenda pits her against more traditional members of the KMT.

item.title: C5+1 Summit: What’s at Stake for the US and Central Asia
item.description: Kazakhstan and its neighbors continue to balance their ties with Washington alongside their deep economic and security links with Russia and China.

item.title: Why Standing by South Korea’s Hanwha Is a US Imperative
item.description: When China sanctioned units of Hanwha Ocean for its shipbuilding activities in the U.S., Washington's response was a welcome change.

item.title: Trump and Xi Revive the Ghost of the G2
item.description: A seemingly offhand remark from Trump signals the return – at least rhetorically – of an idea once proposed and dismissed by both Washington and Beijing.

item.title: Uzbekistan’s Water Crisis Spells Debts for Farmers
item.description: At a time when saving water has become a matter of vital importance, it is no less crucial to monitor how the allocated funds are used.

item.title: Game Changer: Trump Approves South Korea’s Nuclear Submarine Ambition
item.description: The decision will have major implications for the South Korea-U.S. alliance and beyond.

item.title: Nepal Counts the Economic Cost of the Gen Z Uprising
item.description: The new government has tried to woo businesses, but it will take more than tax cuts and easy loans to convince them to make long-term bets.

item.title: Trump Plays Offense in China’s Backyard
item.description: His Cambodia charm offensive is the new normal in U.S. foreign policy.

item.title: Will AI Kill the Firm?
item.description: For centuries, the firm has organized economic life, translating human labor into value through hierarchy and routine. But as agentic AI begins to perform the managerial work of coordinating and decision-making, the institutions that once defined modern capitalism are starting to give way.

item.title: Life in Lint: The Cost of India’s Textile Recycling
item.description: Workers trade off their health and welfare for a precarious living.

item.title: Economics Is Europe’s Tool for Everything
item.description: Why the bloc always seeks economic solutions to its political problems.

item.title: Former President Duterte to Appeal ICC Ruling Affirming Its Jurisdiction
item.description: Duterte's lawyers content that the court did not initiate a full-fledged investigation until after the Philippines withdrew from the court in 2019.

item.title: The Fantasy of a New Middle East
item.description: Israel cannot destroy its way to peace.

item.title: How to Put IR Theory Into Practice
item.description: American strategists should think more like social scientists.

item.title: Timor-Leste Shouldn’t Have to Buy Its ASEAN Seat With Silence
item.description: Myanmar's military junta has used the bloc's procedures to silence calls for accountability made by the organization's newest member state.
